title: Introduction

subsections.title: General Operation
content: Aquavx Pro systems have a flexible set of analog and digital inputs and outputs, along with the ability to read and write to Modbus TCP and RTU registers. See table below to compare I/O options for the Pro and ProPlus.
Alarms and Event History can be viewed locally on the Aquavx Pro controller, allowing the operator an easy method of determining how the system has been operating over time.
Aquavx Pro supports use of a security passcode at the unit, preventing unwanted changes to the system. The factory set passcode is 1 1 1 1.
Aquavx Pro reports information to the RemoteIQ hosted-service system based on the following:
lists: Time interval
Channels going into/out of alarm conditions
Delta reporting when a channel changes by a user definable amount
Daily statistics reported at the end of day

subsections.title: Store and Forward Buffer
content: Aquavx Pro has a large and forward buffer to save any records that should be sent to the internet hosted-service in the event that communication to the hosted-service has been interrupted for any reason. When communication is re-established, the buffer is sent all at once.
The buffer can be cleared through the Maintenance Menu â€“ either one entry at a time or all entries at once.

The Aquavxâ„¢ Pro is a premium remote monitoring, control, and data-acquisition device powered by the RemoteIQâ„¢ Water cloud platform. It provides operators with real-time visibility and control of critical field assets such as pumps, tanks, and lift stations.

The Aquavx Pro delivers many of the capabilities typically found in PLC-based SCADA systemsâ€”including automation logic, alarm management, and data loggingâ€”but in a smaller, more cost-effective form factor. Its built-in 4G LTE connectivity to the RemoteIQ Cloud eliminates the need for third-party networking hardware, external modems, or software licensing.

Operators receive instant alarm notifications via voice, text, or email whenever power is lost, communication is interrupted, or a system limit is exceeded. Intuitive graphics and dashboards within RemoteIQ Water provide live insights into site performance, enabling quick decisions and proactive maintenance.

Unlike traditional SCADA installations, the Aquavx Pro requires no custom engineering, IT infrastructure, or recurring software maintenance. The unit includes an 18-hour onboard backup battery, with an option to extend runtime up to 72 hours. When AC power is lost, the controller automatically switches to battery operation and maintains output power for critical sensor loops, ensuring continuous monitoring and alarm capability.

subsections.title: Overview
content: The Aquavx Pro controller features an intuitive front panel interface for viewing system data, alarms, and configuration menus. The front panel consists of five soft keys below the LCD display and six side-mounted buttons for navigation and control.

subsections.title: Soft Keys (Below Display)
content: Each of the five soft keys has a dynamic function indicated by an icon on the LCD screen above it. These provide quick access to common operations.
lists: Scroll Channels: Starts/Stops automatic scrolling through the list of data channels.
Manual Scroll: Press button to scroll through the channels one screen at a time.
Channel List: Displays the full list of all available channels and data registers for review.
View Alarms: Opens the active alarm list to view current system alerts.
Settings / Status / Config: Opens system configuration, device status, and setup menus.

title: Channel Configuration
content: Aquavx Pro channels can be configured by navigating to the channel configuration section on the screen. The following parameters can be configured for each channel. Each channel displays data from a source register, which in turn stores the raw data from physical analog and digital inputs and outputs, Modbus registers, internal device health data, and calculated values.
Common Channel Parameters
Analog Channel Parameters
Analog channels are used for variable signals such as pressure, level, or temperature. They support decimal precision and engineering unit labels.
Digital Channel Parameters
Digital channels are used for discrete (on/off) signals such as pump run status, float switch state, or alarm indicators.

When configuring channels via the HMI, ensure each channel is properly labeled and mapped to its correct data register. For analog inputs, set the display precision and units. For digital inputs, define meaningful ON/OFF labels and confirm the correct bit number if using packed Modbus registers.

lists: For most industrial transmitters, use Input Type = 2 (4â€“20mA).

subsections.title: Setup Tips
lists: Ensure only one device on the network shares the same IP address.

When using Modbus TCP Server, confirm the listening port (typically 502) is not blocked by firewalls.
The TrivialFTP server is used for firmware or configuration file transfers; ensure the selected port does not conflict with Modbus ports.
Disable both Client and Server functions before changing DHCP or IP addressing parameters.

subsections.title: Configuration Notes
lists: All devices on the Modbus RTU network must share the same baud rate, parity, and stop bit settings.
Termination resistors should be enabled only on the first and last device in the RS-485 daisy chain.
Use twisted-pair, shielded cable for RS-485 wiring to reduce electrical noise.
Ensure each Modbus slave device has a unique address to avoid communication conflicts.
After switching between RS-232 and RS-485 modes, power-cycle the controller to apply the changes.
Use short cable runs when possible to minimize signal degradation and reflection on the RS-485 bus.

title: Duplex and Simplex Pump Control Setup

subsections.title: Overview
content: The Pump Control feature in your Aquavx Pro system manages how the system  automatically turns on and off pumps to control liquid levels in a tank or wet well. This guide explains how to review and change pump settings using the controller's built-in display and buttons.

subsections.title: What This System Does
content: Automatically starts and stops pumps to keep the tank level within set limits.
Alternates between pumps to prevent wear and tear (if two pumps are installed).
Raises alarms for fault conditions like pump failure or high liquid levels.

subsections.title: Navigating the Menu
content: Use the arrow keys to scroll, the Enter button to select, and the Back or Cancel button to go back.
To find Pump Control settings:
From the main screen, press the Menu button.
Scroll to Function Block Configs and press Enter.
Select Pump Control
Follow prompts to view or edit pump control parameters.

subsections.title: Settings
content: Level Setpoints
Lead On: Level where the first pump turns on.
Lag On: Level where the second pump turns on (if needed).
All Off: Level where both pumps turn off.
High Alarm / Low Alarm: Trigger visual or audible alarms if levels go outside safe range.
Delays and Timers
Debounce: Prevents pump from reacting to quick fluctuations.
Start Delay: Wait time before turning pump on.
Restart Delay: Time before same pump can start again.
Max On Time: Limits how long a pump can stay on in one cycle.
tables: Turns the Pump Control system on or off.
Set to "Drain" (for wet wells) or "Fill" (for storage tanks).
1 for single pump, 2 for duplex stations.
Set to "Auto" to rotate pumps and balance usage.
Choose "Level Sensor" for ultrasonic or pressure sensors, or "Floats" for mechanical switches.

subsections.title: How to Edit a Parameter
content: Navigate to the setting using arrows.
Press Enter to select.
Use arrow keys to adjust the value.
Press Enter again to confirm.

For example, to change the Lead On Level:
- Go to 'Lead On Setpt'
- Press Enter, adjust level (e.g., 35.0)
- Press Enter again to save

subsections.title: Tips
content: Watch the Pump Status screen to see current level and pump state.
Use Favorites keys (F1â€“F4) to jump quickly to pages like Pump Status, Alarms, or Events.
If unsure about a setting, contact your system technician.

title: Pump Status and HOA
content: Once you have set up pump control, you can monitor pump control activity as well as a virtual Hand/OFF/Auto interface (HOA) via the pump control status screen.

subsections.title: Overview
content: The Peer-to-Peer Networking (also called Push Messaging) feature allows one Aquavx Pro controller to share real-time input/output (I/O) dataâ€”such as tank level, pressure, or pump statusâ€”with one or more remote Aquavx Pro units. Unlike traditional wired Modbus links, this function communicates securely through the RemoteIQ Cloud using each unit's cellular data connection. As long as both devices have a reliable 4G LTE connection to the cloud, they can exchange data instantly, no matter where they are located geographically.
Sharing a tank-level signal from one site to control a booster or lift-station pump at another.
Sending status, alarms, or flow information to a remote monitoring site.
Creating distributed control networks without the need for dedicated private radio systems.
lists: Typical applications include:

subsections.title: Push / Peer-to-Peer Parameters
tables: A representative name for the peer-to-peer link (up to 31 characters).
Defines the role of the unit. 0 = Disabled, 1 = Send, 2 = Receive.
When Mode = Send, this is the local channel whose data will be transmitted. When Mode = Receive, this is the destination channel where incoming data will be written.
(Send Mode only) The minimum analog-value change required to trigger a new transmission (float).
The change in value must remain continuous for this duration before sending (0â€“3600 s).
The 15-digit IMEI of the remote Aquavx Pro device. This value links the sender and receiver through MQTT subscriptions on the RemoteIQ Cloud.

subsections.title: Configuration Notes
lists: Each 'Send' unit can transmit to one or more 'Receive' units as long as each receiver's Peer IMEI matches the sender's hardware IMEI.
For analog signals, use the Delta parameter to avoid unnecessary cellular data usage caused by minor fluctuations.
Ensure that both Modbus and Peer-to-Peer communications are configured independentlyâ€”they can operate simultaneously without interference.
The Debounce setting helps eliminate noise or rapidly oscillating values before a transmission is triggered.
A reliable cellular signal (RSSI > -95 dBm) is recommended for consistent updates.
Verify cloud connectivity through the Cell Status page before enabling Push links.
After editing Push parameters, save and reboot the controller to activate new links.
